chary.example: Jack was wary of GRE words that looked similar, because they usually had different definitions; not so with chary, a word that he began to use interchangeably with wary.

check.example: Deserted for six months, the property began to look more like a jungle and less like a residence - weeds grew unchecked in the front yard.

check.example: When government abuses are not kept in check, that government is likely to become autocratic.

coalesce.example: Over time, the various tribes coalesced into a single common culture with one universal language.

commensurate.example: The convicted felon's life sentence was commensurate to the heinousness of his crime.

complicit.example: nature. While the grand jury cleared the senator of all criminal charges, in the public mind he was still complicit in the corruption.

compound.example: Her headache was compounded by the construction crew outside, which had six jackhammers going at the same time.

concede.meaning: give over; surrender, relinquish, yield (a possession, right, or privilege)

concomitant.example: connection with another Concomitant with his desire for nature was a desire for the culture and energy of a big city.

conducive.example: Studying in a quiet room is conducive to learning; studying in a noisy environment makes learning more difficult.

conflagration.example: In the summer months, conflagrations are not uncommon in the southwest, do to the heat and lack of rain.

consecrate.example: At the church of Notre Dame in France, the new High Altar was consecrated in 1182.

constituent.example: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.

constituent.example: The constituents of the metal alloy are nickle, copper, and tin.

constraint.example: He found pop music a constraint on his ability to learn and preferred to listen to classical musical while studying.

consummate.example: Tyler was the consummate musician: he was able to play the guitar, harmonica, and the drum at the same time.

contingent.example: A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.

dearth.example: I am surprised by the dearth of fast food chains; this is America and I assumed they were on every street.

debase.example: The third-rate script so debased the film that not even the flawless acting could save it from being a flop.

denouement.example: outcome of a complex sequence of events At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.

empiricism.example: as a way to gain insight and knowledge Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.
empiricism.meaning: any method that derives knowledge from experience, used in experimental science

emulate.example: To really become fluent in a new language, emulate the speech patterns and intonation of people who speak the language.

enamored.example: She is completely enamored with Justin Bieber, and goes to all his concerts on the East coast.
enamored.meaning: strongly attracted to, in love with

encumber.example: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

endemic.example: Irish cuisine makes great use of potatoes, but ironically, the potato is not endemic to Ireland.
endemic.meaning: native; regularly found in a certain area or group of people

enervate.example: John preferred to avoid equatorial countries; the intense sun would always leave him enervated after he'd spent the day sightseeing.
enervate.meaning: make (someone) feel drained of energy or vitality; to sap energy from

engender.example: The restrictions of the Treaty of Versailles were so severe that they engendered deep hatred and resentment in the German people.

enjoin.example: The government agency enjoined the chemical company to clean up the hazardous dump it had created over the years.
enjoin.meaning: give instructions to or direct somebody to do something with authority

enmity.example: Charles rude remark toward Sarah yesterday was due to his illness, not due to any real enmity toward Sarah.

enormity.example: The enormity of Pol Pot's regime is hard to capture in words - within months hundreds of thousands of Cambodians lost their lives.
enormity.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

enthrall.example: She was so enthralled by the movie that she never heard people screaming, "Fire! Fire!" in the neighboring theater.

entice.example: Harold enticed his wife, Maude, to go on a vacation to Hawaii, with promises of luaus on the beach and all-you-can-eat seafood buffets.
entice.meaning: lure, tempt by offering pleasure or advantage

entrenched.example: By the time we reach 60-years old, most of our habits are so entrenched that it is difficult for us to change.
entrenched.meaning: firmly established and unlikely to change; ingrained (of a habit)

enumerate.example: The survey enumerates the number of happy workers and the number of unhappy workers.
I sat and listened as she enumerated all of the things she did not like about the past three months.

ephemeral.example: The lifespan of a mayfly is ephemeral, lasting from a few hours to a couple of days.

epigram.example: My favorite epigram from Mark Twain is "A man who carries a cat by the tail learns something he can learn no other way."

epiphany.example: Gary one day had an epiphany that he was a people person; he prompty quit his factory job and began working as a salesman.
epiphany.meaning: a sudden revelation or moment of insight

eponym.example: named Alexandria, Egypt is an eponym because it is named after Alexander the Great.
eponym.meaning: the name derived from a person (real or imaginary); the person for whom something is

equitable.example: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting - at least until the ice cream is gone.
equitable.meaning: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience

equivocal.example: The findings of the study were equivocal - the two researchers had different opinions on what the results signified.
equivocal.meaning: confusing or ambiguous; open to more than one interpretation

equivocate.example: After Sharon brought the car home an hour after her curfew, she equivocated when her parents pointedly asked her where she had been.
equivocate.meaning: to speak vaguely, usually with the intention to mislead or deceive

eradicate.example: I tried eradicating the mosquitos in my apartment with a rolled up newspaper, but there were too many of them.

err.example: He erred in thinking that "indigent" and "indignant" were synonyms.

errant.example: Unlike his peers, who spent their hours studying in the library, Matthew preferred errant walks through the university campus.
errant.meaning: wandering; straying from the accepted course or standards

erratic.example: It came as no surprise to pundits that the President's attempt at re-election floundered; even during his term, support for his policies was erratic, with an approval rating jumping anywhere from 30 to 60 percent.
erratic.meaning: unpredictable, not even or regular in pattern or movement

ersatz.example: The car dealer's ersatz laughter was immediately followed by a price quote, one that Shelley found highly inflated.

erudite.example: Before the Internet, the library was typically were you would find erudite readers.

eschew.example: Politicians are the masters of eschewing morals; academics are the masters of eschewing clarity.
eschew.meaning: avoid and stay away from deliberately

esoteric.example: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pasttime.
esoteric.meaning: likely to be understood by only a small number of people with specialized knowledge

espouse.example: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.
espouse.meaning: to adopt or support an idea or cause

estimable.example: After serving thirty years, in which he selflessly served the community, Judge Harper was one of the more estimable people in town.

ethereal.example: Because she dances with an ethereal style, ballet critics have called her Madame Butterfly.

euphoria.example: The euphoria of winning her first gold medal in the 100 meter dash overwhelmed Shelly-Ann Fraser and she wept tears of immense joy.
euphoria.meaning: a feeling or state of intense excitement and happiness

evanescent.example: The storm flashed into existence above us and lasted only a short time - an evanescent turbulence of wind and cloud.

evasive.example: His responses were clearly evasive; he obviously did not want to take on any responsibility or any new work. | Every time I call the bank, I receive the same evasive answers about our mortgage and never get a clear response.
evasive.meaning: deliberately vague or ambiguous, responding only indirectly

evenhanded.example: Teachers often have trouble being evenhanded to all of their varied students.

exacerbate.example: Her sleeplessness exacerbated her cold - when she woke up the next day, her sinuses were completely blocked.

exacting.example: Though his childhood piano teacher was so exacting, Max is thankful now, as a professional pianist.

exalt.example: The teenagers exalted the rock star, covering their bedrooms with posters of him.

exasperate.example: As a child, I exasperated my mother with strings of never-ending questions.

excoriate.example: Entrusted with the prototype to his company's latest smartphone, Larry, during a late night karaoke bout, let the prototype slip into the hands of a rival company - the next day Larry was excoriated, and then fired.

excruciating.example: After the boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.

execrate.example: Though the new sitcom did decently in the ratings, Nelson railed against the show, saying that it was nothing more than an execrable pastiche of tired cliches and canned laughter.

exegesis.example: The Bible is fertile ground for exegesis - over the past five centuries there have been as many interpretations as there are pages in the Old Testament.
exegesis.meaning: critical explanation or analysis, especially of a text

exemplar.example: Lena's homework is on the wall because it is an exemplar of clean, neat, and thoughtful work.

exemplify.example: Lincoln exemplified the best of not only America, but also the potential greatness that exists within each person.
exemplify.meaning: serve as an example of, embody

exemplify.example: Please present some case studies that exemplify the results that you claim in your paper.
exemplify.meaning: illustrate or clarify by giving an example of

exhort.example: Nelson's parents exhorted him to study medicine, urging him to choose a respectable profession; intransigent, Nelson left home to become a graffiti artist.

exiguity.example: After two months at sea, the exiguity of the ship's supplies forced them to search for fresh water and food.

exonerate.example: The document clearly indicated that Nick was out of the state at the time of the crime, and so served to exonerate him of any charges.
exonerate.meaning: pronounce not guilty of criminal charges

exorbitant.example: Shelley made one exorbitant purchase after another, buying new clothes and taking vacations even though she earned a limited salary.
exorbitant.meaning: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation

expansive.example: After a few sips of cognac, the octogenarian shed his irascible demeanor and became expansive, speaking fondly of the "good old days".
expansive.meaning: communicative, and prone to talking in a sociable manner
expansive.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

expound.example: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.

expunge.example: When I turned 18, all of the shoplifting and jaywalking charges were expunged from my criminal record.

expurgate.example: The censor expurgated every reference to sex and drugs, converting the rapper's raunchy flow into a series of bleeps.

extant.example: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.
extant.meaning: the opposite of extinct; still in existence, surviving

extenuating.example: The jury was hardly moved by the man's plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.
extenuating.meaning: making less guilty or more forgivable, mitigating

extrapolate.example: By extrapolating from the data on the past three months, we can predict a 5% increase in traffic to our website.
extrapolate.meaning: draw from specific cases for more general cases

facetious.example: Facetious behavior will not be tolerated during sex eduation class; it's time for all of you to treat these matters like mature adults.
facetious.meaning: joking (often inappropriately), treating serious issues with deliberately inappropriate humor, humorous

facile.example: Many news shows provide facile explanations to complex politics, so I prefer to read the in-depth reporting of The New York Times.
facile.meaning: arrived at without due care or effort; lacking depth

factious.example: The controversial bill proved factious, as dissension even within parties resulted

factitious.example: The defendant's story was largely factitious and did not accord with eyewitness testimonies

fallacious.example: The widespread belief that Eskimos have forty different words for snow is fallacious, based on one false report.
fallacious.meaning: based on a mistaken belief or faulty reasoning

fastidious.example: Whitney is fastidious about her shoes, arranging them on a shelf in a specific order, each pair evenly spaced.

fawn.example: The media fawned over the handsome new CEO, praising his impeccable sense of style instead of asking more pointed questions.
fawn.meaning: try to gain favor by extreme flattery
fawn.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

feckless.example: Two years after graduation, Charlie still lived with his parents and had no job, becoming more feckless with each passing day.

fecund.example: The artist had entered a fecund period, producing three masterpieces in the span of two months.

fell.example: For fans of the Harry Potter series, the fell Lord Voldemort, who terrorized poor Harry for seven lengthy installments, has finally been vanquished by the forces of good - unless, that is, JK Rowling decides to come out of retirement.
fell.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ferret.example: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure words.
ferret.meaning: drive out of hiding, discover by an assiduous search
ferret.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

fete.example: After World War II, war heroes were feted at first but quickly forgotten.

fickle.example: She was so fickle in her politics, it was hard to pinpoint her beliefs; one week she would embrace a side, and the next week she would denounce it.
fickle.meaning: changeable, liable to unpredictable change, especially in loyalties or affections

finagle.example: Steven was able to finagle one of the last seats on the train by convincing the conductor that his torn stub was actually a valid ticket.
finagle.meaning: obtain by dishonest or devious means

firebrand.example: Freddie is a firebrand: every time he walks into the office, he winds up at the center of heated argument.

flag.example: After the three crushing defeats in the last three games, the team's enthusiasm began to flag.
flag.meaning: droop, sink, or settle from or as if from pressure or loss of tautness; become less intense
flag.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

fledgling.example: Murray has years of experience in family practice, but he is just a fledgling in surgery.

fleece.example: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.
fleece.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

flippant.example: Although Sam was trying to honor Mark's sense of humor, many found it quite flippant that he wore a comic nose and glasses mask to Mark's funeral.

flounder.example: Sylvia has excelled at advanced calculus, but ironically, when she has deal with taxes, she flounders.

flummox.example: Mary's behavoir completely flummoxes me: I never have any idea what her motivations might be.
flummox.meaning: be a mystery or bewildering to

flush.example: The exam's passage is flush with difficult words, words that you may have learned only yesterday.

flux.example: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in a state of flux.

foible.example: When their new roommate sat staring at an oak tree for an hour, Marcia thought it indicated a mental problem, but Jeff assured her it was a harmless foible.
foible.meaning: a minor weakness or eccentricity in someone's character

foment.example: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

foolhardy.example: The police regularly face dangerous situations, so for a police officer not to wear his bullet-proof vest is foolhardy.

forlorn.example: After her third pet dog died, Marcia was simply forlorn: this time even the possibility of buying a new dog no longer held any joy.
forlorn.meaning: showing hopelessness; sad and lonely; wretched

forthcoming.example: The President announced that the senators were about to reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.
forthcoming.meaning: about to happen or appear; ready or made available when wanted or needed;

forthcoming.example: As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn't demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.
forthcoming.meaning: at ease in talking to others, communicative

forthright.example: I did not expect the insurance agent to give us any straight answers, but I was pleasent surprised by how forthright he was.
forthright.meaning: direct and outspoken, without subtlety or evasion

fortuitous.example: While the real objects are vastly different sizes in space, the sun and the moon seem to have the same fortuitous size in the sky.

fractious.example: We rarely invite my fractious Uncle over for dinner; he always complains about the food, and usually launches into a tirade on some touchy subject.
fractious.meaning: irritable and is likely to cause disruption

frivolous.example: Compared to Juliet's passionate concern for human rights, Jake's non-stop concern about football seems somewhat frivolous.
frivolous.meaning: not serious in content or attitude or behavior

frugal.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.
frugal.meaning: not spending much money (but spending wisely)

frustrate.example: I thought I would finish writing the paper by lunchtime, but a number of urgent interruptions served to frustrate my plan.
frustrate.meaning: hinder or prevent (the efforts, plans, or desires)
frustrate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

furtive.example: While at work, George and his boss Regina felt the need to be as furtive as possible about their romantic relationship.
furtive.meaning: attempting to avoid attention, because of guilt or fear of trouble; secretive

futile.example: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.

gaffe.example: In a famous gaffe, Vice President Quayle attempted to correct the spelling of a grade school student, only to find that the child was correct.
gaffe.meaning: a socially awkward or tactless act

gainsay.example: I can't gainsay a single piece of evidence James has presented, but I still don't trust his conclusion.

gall.example: Even though Carly was only recently hired, she had the gall to question her boss's judgment in front of the office.
In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of her ex-boyfriend to all his co-workers and professional contacts.
gall.meaning: feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill-will

galvanize.example: At mile 23 of his first marathon, Kyle had all but given up, until he noticed his friends and family holding a banner that read, "Go Kyle"; galvanized, he broke into a gallop, finishing the last three miles in less than 20 minutes.
galvanize.meaning: to excite or inspire (someone) to action

gambit.example: Randy played a gambit, telling his boss that he would leave at the end of the week if he didn't get a raise.
gambit.meaning: a manuveur or risk in a game or conversation, designed to secure an advantage

garrulous.example: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.
garrulous.meaning: excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters

gauche.example: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.
gauche.meaning: socially awkward and incapable; lacking social polish

genial.example: Betty is a genial young woman: everyone she meets is put at ease by her elegance and grace.

genteel.example: A live string quartet would provide a more genteel air to the wedding than would a folk singer.
genteel.meaning: refined in taste and manners, well-bred, elegant

germane.example: The professor wanted to tell the jury in detail about his new book, but the lawyer said it wasn't germane to the charges in the cases.

gerrymander.example: Years ago, savvy politicians had gerrymandered the city center to ensure their re-election.
gerrymander.meaning: to manipulate voting districts in order to favor a particular political party

glean.example: Herb has given us no formal statement about his background, but from various hints, I have gleaned that he grew up in difficult circumstances.
glean.meaning: collect information bit by bit, from various sources

glib.example: I have found that the more glib the salesman, the worse the product.
glib.meaning: speaking with ease but without sincerity

glut.example: The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.
In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.

goad.example: Doug did not want to enter the race, but Jim, through a steady stream of taunts, goaded him into signing up for it.
goad.meaning: provoke or annoy so as to stimulate a reaction

gossamer.example: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate that they are often damaged.
gossamer.meaning: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy

graft.example: In countries with rampant graft, getting a driver's license can require no more than paying an official.
graft.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

grandiloquent.example: The dictator was known for his grandiloquent speeches, puffing his chest out and using big, importantsounding words.

gregarious.example: Often we think that great leaders are those who are gregarious, always in the middle of a large group of people; yet, as Mahatma Gandhi and many others have shown us, leaders can also be introverted.
gregarious.meaning: sociable, to be likely to socialize with others

grovel.example: Every time Susan comes to the office, Frank grovels as if she were about to fire.
grovel.meaning: lie or crawl abjectly on the ground, show submission
grovel.meaning_bg: пълзя, търкалям се, унижавам се, подмазвам се

guffaw.example: Whenever the jester fell to the ground in mock pain, the king guffawed, exposing his yellow, fang-like teeth.

guileless.example: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but I then found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.
guileless.meaning: free of deceit; innocent and without deception

gumption.example: Wallace Stegner lamented the lack of gumption in the U.S. during the sixties, claiming that no young person knew the value of work.

hackneyed.example: Cheryl rolled her eyes when she heard the lecturer's hackneyed advice to "be true to yourself."
hackneyed.meaning: lacking significance because it has been overused

hagiographic.example: Most accounts of Tiger Woods life were hagiographic, until, that is, his affairs made headlines.
hagiographic.meaning: excessively flattering toward someone's life or work

hail.example: Many college superstar athletes are hailed as the next big thing, but then flop at the professional level.
hail.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

halcyon.example: prosperity The first decade after WWI was a halcyon period in America with new-found wealth and rapidly improving technology.
halcyon.meaning: idyllically calm and peaceful; suggesting happy tranquillity; marked by peace and

hamper.example: As the rain water began to collect in pools on the highway, it began to hamper the flow of traffic.
hamper.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

hamstrung.example: The FBI has made so many restriction on the local police that they are absolutely hamstrung, unable to accomplish anything.

haphazard.example: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.
haphazard.meaning: lacking any obvious principle of organization; random, unsystematic

harangue.example: Dinner at Billy's was more a punishment than a reward, since anyone who sat at the dinner table would have to listen to Billy's father's interminable harangues against the government.
harangue.meaning: a long pompous speech; a tirade

harangue.example: Tired of his parents haranguing him about his laziness and lack of initiative, Tyler finally moved out of home at the age of thirty-five.
harangue.meaning: to deliver a long pompous speech or tirade

harbinger.example: The crocus is an early harbinger of spring.

harried.example: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.
harried.meaning: troubled persistently, especially with petty annoyances

haughty.example: The haughty manager didn't believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant his own.

hauteur.example: As soon as she won the lottery, Alice begin displaying a hauteur to her friends, calling them dirty-clothed peasants behind their backs.
hauteur.meaning: overbearing pride evidenced by a superior manner toward inferiors

hector.example: The boss's hectoring manner put off many employees, some of whom quit as soon as they found new jobs.

hedge.example: When asked why he had decided to buy millions of shares at the very moment the tech companies stock soared, the CEO hedged, mentioning something vague about gut instinct.
hedge.meaning: to limit or qualify a statement; to avoid making a direct statement
hedge.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

hegemony.example: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

heretic.example: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.
heretic.meaning: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field (not merely religion)

heyday.example: During the heyday of Prohibition, bootlegging had become such a lucrative business that many who had been opposed to the 18th Amendment began to fear it would be repealed.
heyday.meaning: the time of a person's greatest success, popularity, activity

histrionic.example: Though she received a B- on the test, she had such a histrionic outburst that one would have thought that she'd been handed a death sentence.

hoary.example: Most workout gurus are young, fit people, whereas most yoga gurus are hoary men with long white beards.

hobble.example: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.
hobble.meaning: to hold back the progress of something

hodgepodge.example: Those in attendance represented a hodgepodge of the city's denizens: chimney sweepers could be seen sitting elbow to elbow with stockbrokers.

hoodwink.example: Someone tried to hoodwink Marty with an email telling him that his uncle had just passed away, and to collect the inheritance he should send his credit card information.

hound.example: An implacable foe of corruption, Eliot Ness hounded out graft in all forms - he even helped nab Al Capone.
hound.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

hubris.example: Bill Clinton was criticized for his hubris, since he believed he could get away with anything once in the White House.

humdrum.example: Having grown up in a humdrum suburb, Jacob relished life in New York City after moving.
humdrum.meaning: lacking excitement or variety, boringly monotonous

iconoclast.example: Lady Gaga, in challenging what it means to be clothed, is an iconoclast for wearing a "meat dress" to a prominent awards show.
iconoclast.meaning: somebody who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions

iconoclastic.example: Jackson Pollack was an iconoclastic artist, totally breaking with tradition by splashing paint on a blank canvas.

idiosyncrasy.example: Peggy's numerous idiosyncrasies include wearing mismatched shoes, laughing loudly to herself, and owning a pet aardvark.
idiosyncrasy.meaning: behavioral attribute that is distinctive and peculiar to an individual

ignoble.example: In the 1920s, the World Series was rigged - an ignoble act which baseball took decades to recover from.

ignominious.example: Since the politician preached ethics and morality, his texting of revealing photographs was ignominious, bringing shame on both himself and his party.
ignominious.meaning: deserving or causing public disgrace or shame (about conduct)

illicit.example: Though Al Capone was engaged in many illicit activities, he was finally arrested for income tax evasion, a relatively minor offense.

illustrious.example: Einstein was possibly the most illustrious scientist in recent history.
illustrious.meaning: widely known and esteemed; having or conferring glory

imbibe.example: Plato imbibed Socrates' teachings to such an extent that he was able to write volumes of work that he directly attributed, sometimes word for word, to Socrates.
imbibe.meaning: to drink or absorb as if drinking

imbroglio.example: The chef cook-off featured one gourmand who had the unfortunate distinction of mixing the wrong broths, creating an imbroglio that diners would not soon forget.
imbroglio.meaning: a confusing and potentially embarrassing situation

immaterial.example: The judge found the defendant's comments immaterial to the trial, and summarily dismissed him from the witness stand.

immure.example: The modern supermarket experience makes many feel claustrophobic, as they are immured in walls upon walls of products.

immutable.example: Taxes are one of the immutable laws of the land, so there is no use arguing about paying them.
immutable.meaning: unchangeable, not able to be changed

impartial.example: The judge was not impartial since he had been bribed by the witness's family.
impartial.meaning: free from undue bias or preconceived opinions

impeccable.example: He was impeccably dressed in the latest fashion without a single crease or stain.

impecunious.example: In extremely trying times, even the moderately wealthy, after a few turns of ill-fortune, can become impecunious.

impede.example: Since the police sergeant had to train the pair of new hires, progress in his own case was impeded.

impending.example: The impending doom of our world has been a discussed and debated for 2000 years - maybe even longer.

imperious.example: unworthy Children are imperious with each other before they learn that earning someone's respect is better than demanding.
imperious.meaning: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as

impermeable.example: The sand bags placed on the river formed an impermeable barrier, protecting the town from flooding.
impermeable.meaning: not allowing fluids to pass through

impertinent.example: His neighbors' impertinent curiosity about his lack of dates angered Ted. It was downright rude of them to ask him such personal questions.
impertinent.meaning: disrespectful; improperly forward or bold, insolent, rude

impertinent.example: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer's questions impertinent - after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline's favorite snack was?
impertinent.meaning: not pertinent to a particular manner, irrelevant

impervious.example: I am not impervious to your insults; they cause me great pain.
impervious.meaning: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected

impetuous.example: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.
impetuous.meaning: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation

implacable.example: Win or lose, the coach was always implacable, never giving the athletes an easy practice or a break.
implacable.meaning: unable to be made less angry or hostile

implausible.example: The teacher found it implausible that the student was late to school because he had been kidnapped by outlaws on horseback.
implausible.meaning: describing a statement that is not believable

implicate.example: By saying that some of the guests were uncomfortable, the manager implicated to the hotel staff that it needed to be more dilligent.
The crime boss was implicated for a long list of crimes, ranging from murder to disturbing the peace.
implicate.meaning: incriminate, show to be involved in a crime

imponderable.example: According to many lawmakers, the huge variety of factors affecting society make devising an efficient healthcare system an imponderable task.

importune.example: After weeks of importuning the star to meet for a five-minute interview, the journalist finally got what she wanted.

impregnable.example: As a child, Amy would build pillow castles and pretend they were impregnable fotresses.

improvident.example: Marty was improvident, never putting money aside for the future but spending it on decorating the interior of his home.

imprudent.example: Hitler, like Napoleon, made the imprudent move of invading Russia in winter, suffering even more casualties than Napoleon had.

impudent.example: In an impudent move, the defendant spoke out of order to say terribly insulting things to the judge.

impugn.example: Though many initially tried to impugn Darwin's theory, in scientific circles today, the is idea taken as truth.

impute.example: He imputed his subpar performance on the test to a combination of stress and poor sleep.

inadvertent.example: Although Prohibition was rooted in noble ideals, the inadvertent and costly consequences of making alcohol illegal in the U.S. led its the repeal.
inadvertent.meaning: unintentional, happening by chance or unexpectedly

inanity.example: Bill's poem was nothing more than a list of impressive sounding words, so there was no point in trying to take meaning from the inanity.
inanity.meaning: total lack of meaning or ideas

inarticulate.example: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Black was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.

incense.example: When Herb bought football tickets for a game on the day of their wedding anniversary, Jill was incensed.
incense.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

incessant.example: I don't mind small children in brief doses, but I think the incessant exposure that their parents have to them would quickly wear me down.
incessant.meaning: unceasing, continuing without pause or interruption

inchoate.example: Inchoate ideas about the relation of humans to other animals had been discussed since the Middle Ages but the modern theory really began with Darwin.
inchoate.meaning: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed

incisive.example: The lawyer had an incisive mind, able in a flash to dissect a hopelessly tangled issue and isolate the essential laws at play. | His incisive remarks made us see the fallacy in our plans
incisive.meaning: demonstrating ability to recognize fine distinctions; quick and direct

inclement.example: After a week of inclement weather, we finally are able to go outside and enjoy the sun.
Marcus Aurelius, though a fair man, was inclement to Christians during his reign, persecuting them violently.
inclement.meaning: unkind, cold, showing no mercy (of a person)

incongruous.example: The vast economic inequality of modern society is incongruous with America's ideals.
incongruous.meaning: not in harmony, compatibility or appropriateness

incontrovertible.example: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.
incontrovertible.meaning: necessarily or demonstrably true; impossible to deny or disprove

incorrigible.example: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can't match his fierce individual spirit.
incorrigible.meaning: beyond correction; unable to be changed

incumbent.example: Middle managers at times make important decisions, but real responsibility for the financial well-being of the corporation is ultimately incumbent on the CEO.
incumbent.meaning: necessary for someone as a duty or responsibility

indecorous.example: Eating with elbows on the table is considered indecorous in refined circles.
indecorous.meaning: not in keeping with good taste and propriety; improper

indict.example: The bankrobber was indicted on several major charges, including possession of a firearm.
indict.meaning: to formally charge or accuse of wrong-doing

indifference.example: In an effort to fight indifference, the president of the college introduced a new, stricter grading system.
indifference.meaning: the trait of seeming not to care

indigenous.example: The plants and animals indigenous to Australia are notably different from those indigenous to the U.S-one look at a duckbill platypus and you know you're not dealing with an opossum.

indigent.example: In the so-called Third World, many are indigent and only a privileged few have the resources to enjoy material luxuries.
The indigents, huddled under the overpass, tried to start a small bonfire in the hope of staying warm.

indignant.example: When the cyclist swerved into traffic, it forced the driver to brake and elicited an indignant shout of "Hey, punk, watch where you're going!"

industrious.example: Pete was an industrious student, completing every assignment thoroughly and on time.

ineffable.example: While art critics can occasionally pinpoint a work's greatness, much of why a piece captures our imaginations is completely ineffable.
ineffable.meaning: too sacred to be uttered; defying expression or description

ineluctable.example: For those who smoke cigarettes for years, a major health crisis brought on by smoking is ineluctable.

inequity.example: After decades of racial inequity, the "separate but equal" doctrine was successfully overturned.
inequity.meaning: injustice by virtue of not conforming with rules or standards

inexorable.example: The rise of the computer was an inexorable shift in technology and culture.
inexorable.meaning: unstoppable, impossible to stop or prevent

infelicitous.example: During the executive meeting, the marketing director continued to make infelicitous comments about the CEO's gambling habit.

inflammable.example: It only takes one person to leave an inflammable comment on an Internet thread for that thread to blow up into pages upon pages of reader indignation.
inflammable.meaning_bg: лесно запалим, възбудим, избухлив; подпалвачески, подстрекателски

ingenuity.example: Daedalus was famous for his ingenuity; he was able to fashion his son Icarus with a pair of wings, using wax to hold them together.
ingenuity.meaning: the quality of being clever, original, and inventive

ingenuous.example: Two-years in Manhattan had changed Jenna from an ingenuous girl from the suburbs to a jaded urbanite, unlikely to fall for any ruse, regardless of how elaborate.

ingratiate.example: Even though Tom didn't like his new boss, he decided to ingratiate himself to her in order to advance his career.
ingratiate.meaning: gain favor with somebody by flattering or trying to please them

inimical.example: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

inimitable.example: Mozart's music follows a clear pattern that, anyone could imitate, but his music gives an overall sense of effortlessness that is inimitable.

inkling.example: Lynne speaks four Romance languages, but she doesn't have an inkling about how East Asian languages are structured.
inkling.meaning: a slight knowledge or suspicion, a hint

innocuous.example: Everyone found Nancy's banter innocuous - except for Mike, who felt like she was intentionally picking on him.

inscrutable.example: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.
inscrutable.meaning: impossible to understand or interpret; unfathomable

insidious.example: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.
insidious.meaning: working in a gradual and subtle but very destructive way

insipid.example: The movie director was known for hiring beautiful actors in order to deflect attention away from the insipid scripts he would typically use.

insolent.example: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

insolvent.example: With credit card bills skyrocketing, a shockingly large number of Americans are truly insolvent.
insolvent.meaning: unable to pay one's bills; bankrupt

insouciance.example: Surprisingly, Hank had become a high-powered CEO; his high school friends remembered him as "Hanky Panky", who shrugged off each failed class with insouciance.

insufferable.example: Chester always tried to find some area in which he excelled above others; unsurprisingly, his co-workers found him insufferable and chose to exclude him from daily luncheons out.

intermittent.example: The intermittent thunder continued and the night was punctuated by cracks of lightning - a surreal sleepless night.

internecine.example: The guerilla group, which had become so powerful as to own the state police, was finally destroyed by an internecine conflict.
internecine.meaning: (of conflict) within a group or organization

intimate.example: At first Manfred's teachers intimated to his parents that he was not suited to skip a grade; when his parents protested, teachers explicitly told them that, notwithstanding the boy's precocity, he was simply too immature to jump to the 6th grade.
intimate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

intimation.example: At first the hostess tried intimation, praising the benefits of cutlery; when Cecil continued eating with his hands, the hostess told him to use a fork at dinner.

intransigent.example: Despite many calls for mercy, the judge remained intransigent, citing strict legal precedence.
intransigent.meaning: refusing to change views or course of action

intrepid.example: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimate leads to his downfall.

inundate.example: The newsroom was inundated with false reports that only made it more difficult for the newscasters to provide an objective account of the bank robbery.
inundate.meaning: to flood or overwhelm with things to be dealt with

inure.example: Three years of Manhattan living has inured her to the sound of wailing sirens; she could probably sleep through the apocalypse.
inure.meaning: to make accustomed to something unpleasant

invective.example: The Internet has unleashed the invectives in many of us; many people post stinging criticism on the comments section underneath newspaper articles or YouTube videos.

inveterate.example: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.
inveterate.meaning: habitual; having a particular habit, activity, or interest that is long-established and unlikely to change

invidious.example: At a time when many others in the office were about to be laid off, many considered Cheryl's fine clothes that day an invidious display.
invidious.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

inviolable.example: Too many the grass at Wimbledon is inviolable and only greater tennis players are able to enjoy a game there.
inviolable.meaning: never to be broken, infringed, or dishonored

inviolate.example: While the literary critic subjected most of the classics to the harshest reviews, he regarded Cervantes as inviolate, and had nothing but praise for him.

involved.example: The physics lecture became so involved that the undergraduate's eyes glazed over.

irascible.example: If Arthur's dog is not fed adequately, he becames highly irascible, even growling at his own shadow.

irk.example: My little sister has a way of irking and annoying me like no other person.

irrefutable.example: The existence of life on earth is irrefutable; the existence of intelligent life on earth is still hotly debated.

irresolute.example: He stood irresolute at the split in the trail, not sure which route would lead back to the camp.
irresolute.meaning: uncertain how to act or proceed

irrevocable.example: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.
irrevocable.meaning: incapable of being retracted or revoked

itinerant.example: Doctors used to be itinerant, traveling between patients' homes.
itinerant.meaning: traveling from place to place to work

jargon.example: To those with little training in medicine, the jargon of doctors can be very difficult to understand.
jargon.meaning: language used by a special group, technical terminology

jaundiced.example: Shelly was jaundiced towards Olivia; though the two had once been best friends, Olivia had become class president, prom queen, and, to make matters worse, the girlfriend of the one boy Shelly liked.
jaundiced.meaning: to be biased against due to envy or prejudice

jejune.example: Although many top chefs have secured culinary foam's popularity in haute cuisine, Waters criticizes it for being jejune and unfilling.
Her boss further cemented his reuptation for being jejune after throwing a fit when the water cooler wasn't refilled.

jingoism.example: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

jingoist.example: In the days leading up to war, a nation typically breaks up into the two opposing camps: doves, who do their best to avoid war, and jingoists, who are only too eager to wave national flags from their vehicles and vehemently denounce those who do not do th
jingoist.meaning: a person who thinks that their country should be at war

jocular.example: My uncle was always in a jocular mood at family gatherings, messing up people's hair and telling knockknock jokes to anyone who would listen.

jovial.example: The political candidate and his supporters were jovial once it was clear that she had won.

jubilant.example: My hardwork paid off, and I was jubilant to receive a perfect score on the GRE.
jubilant.meaning: full of high-spirited delight because of triumph or success

juggernaut.example: Napoleon was considered a juggernaut until he decided to invade Russia in winter; after which, his once indomitable army was decimated by cold and famine.
juggernaut.meaning: a force that cannot be stopped

junta.example: As dangerous of a threat as North Korea is, some analysts believe that were a junta suddenly to gain power, it could be even more unpredictable and bellicose than the current leadership
junta.meaning: a military or political group that rules a country after taking power by force

juxtapose.example: The meaning of her paintings comes from a classical style which juxtaposes modern themes.

kowtow.example: Paul kowtowed to his boss so often the boss herself became nauseated by his sycophancy.
kowtow.meaning: to bow or act in a subservient manner

laborious.example: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in King Salmon, Alaska.

lacerate.example: The teacher was fired for lacerating a student who wrote a poor essay.
lacerate.meaning: deeply hurt the feelings of; distress
lacerate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

lachrymose.example: Lachrymose and depressed, Alexei Alexandrovich walked two miles home in the rain after learning that his wife was having an affair.

laconic.example: While Martha always swooned over the hunky, laconic types in romantic comedies, her boyfriends inevitably were very talkative - and not very hunky. Many of the characters portrayed by Clint Eastwood are laconic types: strong men of few words
laconic.meaning: using very few words, brief and to the point

lambast.example: Showing no patience, the manager utterly lambasted the sales team that lost the big account.

lampoon.example: Mark Twain understood that lampooning a bad idea with humor was the most effective criticism.

languid.example: As the sun beat down and the temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.
languid.meaning: showing a disinclination for physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed

languish.example: Stranded in the wilderness for four days, the hiker languished, eating protein bars and nuts.

largess.example: Uncle Frank was known for his largess, so his nephew was sad when he did not receive a present for his birthday.

lascivious.example: Lolita is a challenging novel for many, not necessarily because of the elevated prose style but because of the depravity of the main character, Humbert Humbert, who, as an old, lascivious man, falls in love with a girl.

laudable.example: To say that Gandhi's actions were laudable is the greatest understatement; he overthrew an empire without violence.

leery.example: Without checking his references and talking to previous employers, I am leery of hiring the candidate.
leery.meaning: suspicious, cautious, openly distrustful and unwilling to confide

lethargic.example: Nothing can make a person more lethargic than a big turkey dinner.

licentious.example: Unscrupulously seducing the daughter of his host, Don Juan felt no qualms about the immorality of his licentious behavior.
licentious.meaning: amoral, lustful, lewd and lascivious, unrestrained, promiscuous

limpid.example: Her limpid prose made even the most recondite subjects accessible to all.

lionize.example: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

litany.example: Mr. Rogers spoke to a Senate committee and did not give a litany of reasons to keep funding the program, but instead, appealed to the basic human decency of all present.
litany.meaning: any long and tedious account of something

loath.example: I was loath to leave the concert before my favorite band finished playing.
loath.meaning: unwillingness to do something contrary to your custom (usually followed by 'to')

lucid.example: Though Walters writes about physics and time travel, his writing is always lucid, so readers with little scientific training can understand difficult concepts.

lugubrious.example: At the funeral, lugubrious songs filled the small church.

macabre.example: Edgar Allen Poe was considered the master of the macabre; his stories vividly describe the moment leading up to - and often those moments after - a grisly death.
macabre.meaning: horrifying because of involvement with or depiction of death; gruesome

machinate.example: The rebels met at night in an abandoned barn to machinate.
machinate.meaning: engage in plotting or enter into a conspiracy, swear together

magisterial.example: Though she was only a third grade teacher, Ms. Martinet was magisterial in dealing with her class, lording over them like a queen.
magisterial.meaning: offensively self-assured or given to exercising unwarranted power
magisterial.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

magnanimous.example: He was a great sportsman: in defeat he was complementary and in victory he was magnanimous.
magnanimous.meaning: noble and generous in spirit, especially towards a rival or someone less powerful

maintain.example: The scientist maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

maladroit.example: As a child she was quite maladroit, but as an adult, she has become an adept dancer.
maladroit.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

malady.example: The town was struck by a malady throughout the winter that left most people sick in bed for two weeks.

malapropism.example: Whenever I looked glum, my mother would offer to share "an amusing antidote" with me - an endearing malapropism of "anecdote" that never failed to cheer me up.
malapropism.meaning: the confusion of a word with another word that sounds similar

malevolent.example: Villians are known for their malevolent nature, oftentimes inflicting cruetly on others just for enjoyment.

malfeasance.example: Not even the mayor's trademark pearly-toothed grin could save him from charges of malfeasance: while in power, he'd been running an illegal gambling rink in the room behind his office.
malfeasance.meaning: misconduct or wrongdoing (especially by a public official)

malingerer.example: At one time, our country was full of hardworking respectful people, but now it seems that everyone is a malingerer with little inclination to work.
malingerer.meaning: someone shirking their duty by pretending to be sick or incapacitated

malleable.example: The clay became malleable and easy to work with after a little water was added.
malleable.meaning: capable of being shaped or bent (of a material)

malleable.example: My little brother is so malleable that I can convince him to sneak cookies from the cupboard for me.

malodorous.example: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes - the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

martial.example: Americans tend to remember Abraham Lincoln as kindly and wise, not at all martial, despite the fact that he was involved in the fiercest war America has even fought.

martinet.example: The job seemed perfect to Rebecca, until she found out that her boss was a total martinet; after each project the boss would come by to scrutinize - and inevitably criticize - every little detail of the work Rebecca had done.

maudlin.example: Just as those who were alive during the 70's are mortified that they once cavorted about in bellbottoms, many who lived during the 80's are now aghast at the maudlin pop songs they used to enjoy - really, just what exactly is a total eclipse of the heart?

maunder.example: Max liked to maunder down by the seaside and pick up whatever sea shells he would stumble upon.
After drinking two expressos each, the animated couple would maunder loudly, annoying the other patrons in the coffee shop.
maunder.meaning: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly

maverick.example: Officer Kelly was a maverick, rarely following police protocols or adopting the conventions for speech common among his fellow officers.

mawkish.example: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illnesses by the end of the movie.
mawkish.meaning: overly sentimental, to the point that is disgusting

maxim.example: Johnson initially suggests that the secret to business can be summarized in a single maxim but then requires a 300-page book to explain exactly what he means.
maxim.meaning: a short statement expressing a general truth

meander.example: A casual observer might have thought that Peter was meandering through the city, but that day he was actually seeking out those places where he and his long lost love had once visited.

melancholy.example: Hamlet is a figure of tremendous melancholy: he doesn't have a truly cheerful scene throughout the entire play.

melee.example: After enduring daily taunts about my name, I became enraged and pummeled the schoolyard bully and his sycophantic friends in a brutal melee.
melee.meaning: a wild, confusing fight or struggle

mellifluous.example: Chelsea's grandmother thought Franz Schubert's music to be the most mellifluous ever written; Chelsea demurred, and to her grandmother's chagrin, would blast Rihanna on the home stereo speakers.

mendacity.example: I can forgive her for her mendacity but only because she is a child and is seeing what she can get away with.

mendicant.example: Tolstoy was an aristocrat, but he strove to understand the Christianity of the Russian peasants by wandering among them as a mendicant.
mendicant.meaning: a pauper who lives by begging

mercurial.example: The fact that Ella's moods were as mercurial as the weather was problematic for her relationships - it didn't help that she lived in Chicago.
mercurial.meaning: prone to unexpected changes in mood (about a person); fickle

mesmerize.example: The plot and the characters were so well developed that many viewers were mesmerized, unable to move their eyes from the screen for even a single second.

meteoric.example: The early spectacular successes propelled the pitcher to meteoric stardom, but a terribly injury tragically cut short his career.
meteoric.meaning: like a meteor in speed or brilliance or transience

meticulous.example: The Japanese noodle maker was meticulous in making his noodles and would never let another person take over the task.

mettlesome.example: For its raid on the Bin Laden's compound in Abbottabad, Seal Team Six has become, for many Americans, the embodiment of mettle.

misanthrope.example: Hamilton had been deceived so many times in his life that he hid behind the gruff exterior of a misanthrope, lambasting perfect strangers for no apparent reason.

misattribute.example: I made a mistake; I misattributed "Crime and Punishment" to Leo Tolstoy when it was actually written by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.
misattribute.meaning: To erroneously attribute; to falsely ascribe; used especially of authorship.

misconstrue.example: The politician never trusted journalists because he though that they misconstrue his words and misrepresent his positions.

miscreant.example: Come back you miscreant! yelled the woman who just had her purse stollen.
miscreant.meaning: a person who has done something wrong or unlawful.

miser.example: Monte was no miser, but was simply frugal, wisely spending the little that he earned.
miser.meaning: a person who doesn't like to spend money (because he is greedy)

misogynist.example: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.
misogynist.meaning: a person who dislikes women in particular

mitigate.example: I can only spend so much time mitigating your disagreements with your wife, and at certain point, you need to do it on your own.
If it weren't for the mitigating circumstances, he would have certainly lost his job.
mitigate.meaning: lessen the severity of an offense

modicum.example: If my sister had even a modicum of sense, she wouldn't be engaged to that barbarian.
modicum.meaning: a small or moderate or token amount

mollify.example: In the morning, Harriat was unable to mollify Harry, if he happened to become angry, unless he had his cup of coffee.
mollify.meaning: appease the anger of someone; placate, soothe

moment.example: Despite the initial hullabaloo, the play was of no great moment in Hampton's writing career, and within a few years the public quickly forgot his foray into theater arts.
moment.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

moot.example: Since the Board just terminated Steve as the CEO, what the finance committe might have thought of his proposed marketing plan for next year is now a moot point.
moot.meaning: having little or no practical relevance

moot.example: Whether the temperature rise was mainly due to the greenhouse effect was a moot point.
moot.meaning: subject to debate, dispute, or uncertainty

mordant.example: While Phil frequently made mordant remarks about company policy overall, he always was considerably gentler in discussing any person in particular.
mordant.meaning: biting and caustic in thought, manner, or style

moribund.example: Whether you like it or not, jazz as a genre is moribund at best, possibly already dead.
moribund.meaning: being on the point of death; declining rapidly losing all momentum in progress

morose.example: After Stanley found out he was no longer able to go on vacation with his friends, he sat in his room morosely.
morose.meaning: ill-tempered and not inclined to talk; gloomy, sullen

morph.example: The earnestness of the daytime talk shows of the 1970's has morphed into something far more sensational and vulgar: today guests actually standup and threaten to take swings at one another.
morph.meaning: undergo a gradual process of transformation in a seamless way

mulct.example: The so-called magical diet cure simply ended up mulcting Maria out of hundreds of dollars, but did nothing for her weight.

mundane.example: Nancy found doing dishes a thorougly mundane task, although Peter found a kind of Zen pleasure in the chore.
mundane.meaning: repetitive, boring and unshophisticated; not spiritual

mundane.example: Though we think of the pope as someone always dealing in holy matters, he is also concerned with mundane events, such as deciding when to set his alarm each morning.

munificent.example: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

muted.example: Helen preferred muted earth colors, such as green and brown, to the bright pinks and red her sister liked.
muted.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

myopic.example: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn't predict the changes in their industry.
myopic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

myriad.example: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

nadir.example: For many pop music fans, the rap and alternative-rock dominated 90s were the nadir of musical expression.

negligible.example: The GRE tests cumulative knowledge, so if you cram the night before it is, at best, likely to only have a negligible impact on your score.
negligible.meaning: insignificant; so small as to be meaningless

nettlesome.example: Maria found her coworkers cell phone nettlesome, because every few minutes it would buzz to life with another text message.

noisome.example: Each August, when the winds moved in a south easterly direction, the garbage dump would spread noisome vapors through the small town.

nonchalant.example: The twenty-somethings at the coffee shop always irked Sheldon, especially the way in which they acted nonchalantly towards everything, not even caring when Sheldon once spilled his mocha on them.

nonplussed.example: Shirley was totally nonplussed when the angry motorist cut her off and then stuck his finger out the window.
nonplussed.meaning: unsure how to act or respond

nuance.example: Because of the nuances involved in this case, I hired an outside consultant to advice us and help.

obdurate.example: No number of pleas and bribes would get him to change his obdurate attitude.
obdurate.meaning: stubbornly refusing to change opinion or course of action

objurgate.example: The manager spent an hour objurgating the employee in the hopes that he would not make these mistakes again.

obliging.example: Even after all his success, I found him to be accommodating and obliging, sharing with me his "secret tips" on how to gain wealth and make friends.
obliging.meaning: willing to do a service or kindness, helpful

oblique.example: Herbert never explicitly revealed anything negative about Tom's past, but at times he would obliquely suggest that Tom was not as innocent as he seemed.
oblique.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obscure.example: On the Smith's drive through the Grand Canyon, Mr. Smith's big head obscured much of Mrs. Robinson's view, so that she only saw momentary patches of red rock.
obscure.meaning: make unclear; keep from being seen, conceal
obscure.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obscure.example: Many of the biggest movie stars were once obscure actors who got only bit roles in long forgotten films.
obscure.meaning: not important or well known; not discovered
obscure.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obscure.example: Even after I read the poem a fourth time, its meaning was still obscure.
obscure.meaning: not clearly expressed or easily understood; vague, unclear

obsequious.example: The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.
obsequious.meaning: obedient, attentive and flattering to an excessive or servile degree

obstinate.example: The coach suggested improvements Sarah might make on the balance beam, but she remained obstinate, unwilling to modify any of the habits that made her successful in the past.
obstinate.meaning: resistant to guidance or discipline; stubbornly persistent

obstreperous.example: When the teacher asked the obstreperous student simply to bus his tray, the student threw the entire tray on the floor, shouted an epithet, and walked out.
obstreperous.meaning: noisily and stubbornly defiant; willfully difficult to control

obtain.example: The custom of waiting your turn in line does not obtain in some countries, in which many people try to rush to front of the line at the same time.
obtain.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

obtuse.example: discernment Jackson was the most obtuse member of the team: the manager's subtle ironies were always lost on him.
obtuse.meaning: slow to learn or understand; lacking intellectual acuity; lacking in insight or

officious.example: The professor had trouble concentrating on her new theorem, because her officious secretary would barge in frequently reminding her of some trivial detail involving departmental paperwork.
officious.meaning: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner

opaque.example: The meaning of the professor's new research was opaque to most people, so no one asked any questions.
opaque.meaning: not clearly expressed; hard to understand
opaque.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

opulence.example: Russian oligarchs are famous for their opulence, living in fancy homes and dining on expensive cavier.

ornate.example: The ornate Victorian and Edwardian homes spread throughout San Francisco are my favorite part of the city.

ossify.example: Even as a young man, Bob had some bias against poor people, but during his years in social services, his bad opinions ossified into unshiftable views.
ossify.meaning: make rigid and set into a conventional pattern
ossify.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ostentatious.example: Matt wanted to buy stone lions for front of the house, but Cynthia convinced him that such a display would be too ostentatious for a modest house in an unassuming neighborhood.
ostentatious.meaning: pretentious; intended to attract notice and impress others (negative)

ostracize.example: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.
ostracize.meaning: exclude from a community or group

overweening.example: Mark was so convinced of his basketball skills that in his overweening pride he could not fathom that his name was not on the varsity list; he walked up to the basketball coach and told her she had forgotten to add his name.

palatable.example: MIkey didn't partake much in his friends' conversations, but found their presence palatable.
palatable.meaning: acceptable to the taste or mind
palatable.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

palaver.example: During the rain delay, many who had come to see the game palavered, probably hoping that idle chatter would make the time go by faster.
palaver.meaning: speak (about unimportant matters) rapidly and incessantly
palaver.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

palimpsest.example: iterations can still be seen The downtown was a palimpsest of the city's checkered past: a new Starbucks had opened up next to an abandoned, shuttered building, and a freshly asphalted road was inches away from a pothole large enough to swallow a small dog.
palimpsest.meaning: something that has been changed numerous times but on which traces of former

panacea.example: While the company credit card has made most large purchases easier, it is no panacea: some smaller basic transactions still must be conducted in cash.
panacea.meaning: hypothetical remedy for all ills or diseases; a universal solution

panache.example: Jim, with his typical panache, came to the wedding reception with a top hat, a cane, and a long cape covered in sequins.
panache.meaning: flamboyant confidence of style or manner

panegyric.example: Dave asked Andrew to do just a simple toast, but Andrew launched into a full panegyric, enumerating a complete list of Dave's achievements and admirable qualities.

paradoxical.example: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.

paragon.example: Even with the rise of Kobe Bryant, many still believe that Michael Jordon is the paragon for basketball players.
paragon.meaning: model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal

paragon.example: Some say that Athens was the paragon of democracy, but these people often forget that slaves and women were still not allowed to vote.
paragon.meaning: an ideal instance; a perfect embodiment of a concept

pariah.example: The once eminent scientist, upon being found guilty of faking his data, has become a pariah in the research community.

parochial.example: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary tastes were simply too parochial; "After all," she quipped on her blog, "he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food."
parochial.meaning: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook

parsimonious.example: Katie is so parsimonious that she only buys a pair of socks if all of her other socks have holes in them.

parvenu.example: higher class The theater was full of parvenus who each thought that they were surrounded by true aristocrats.
parvenu.meaning: a person who has suddenly become wealthy, but not socially accepted as part of a

pastoral.example: Those who imagine America's countryside as a pastoral region are often disappointed to learn that much of rural U.S. is filled with cornfields extending as far as the eye can see.
pastoral.meaning: related to the countryside in a pleasant sense, rural, peaceful

patent.example: Since the book had been through no fewer than six proof runs, the staff was shocked to see such a patent spelling mistake remaining, right in the middle of the front cover!

patronize.example: She says she genuinely wanted to help me, but instead she patronized me, constantly pointing out how I was inferior to her.
patronize.meaning_bg: отнасям се снизходително, гледам отвисоко на
patronize.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

paucity.example: There is a paucity of jobs hiring today that require menial skills, since most jobs have either been automated or outsourced.

pecuniary.example: The defendent was found guilty and had to serve a period of community service as well as pay pecuniary damages to the client.

pedantic.example: Professor Thompson was regarded as an expert in his field, but his lectures were utterly pedantic, focused on rigorous details of the most trivial conventions in the field.

pedestrian.example: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.
pedestrian.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

peevish.example: Our office manager is peevish, so the rest of us tip-toe around him, hoping not to set off another one of his fits.

pejorative.example: Most psychologists object to the pejorative term "shrink", believing that they expand the human mind, not limit it.
pejorative.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pellucid.example: The professor had a remarkable ability make even the most difficult concepts seem pellucid.

penurious.example: Truly penurious, Mary had nothing more than a jar full of pennies.
Warren Buffett, famous multi-billionaire, still drives a cheap sedan, not because he is penurious, but because luxury cars are gaudy and impractical.

percipient.example: Even the most percipient editor will make an occasional error when proofreading.

peremptory.example: My sister used to peremptorily tell me to do the dishes, a chore I would either do perfunctorily or avoid doing altogether.

perennial.example: Even at the old-timers games, Stan Musial would get the loudest cheer: he was a perennial favorite of the fans there.
perennial.meaning: lasting for a long time, enduring or continually recurring
perennial.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

perfidy.example: The lowest circles in Dante's Inferno were for those who had practiced perfidy, and among these, the very lowest was for those, such as Judas, who had been treacherous to one of their benefactors.
perfidy.meaning: deliberate betrayal; breach of a trust

perfunctory.example: The short film examines modern perfunctory cleaning rituals such as washing dishes, doing laundry and tooth-brushing.
perfunctory.meaning: done routinely and with little interest or care

peripatetic.example: Jim always preferred a peripatetic approach to discovering a city: he felt that he could see so many more details while walking.

pernicious.example: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.
pernicious.meaning: exceedingly harmful; working in a gradual and injurious way

perpetuate.example: If you do not let him do things for himself, you are merely perpetuating bad habits that will be even harder to break in the future.

perquisite.example: Even as the dishwasher at the French restaurant, Josh quickly learned that he had the perquisite of being able to eat terrific food for half the price diners would pay.

perspicacious.example: Many modern observers regard Eisenhower as perspicacious, particularly in his accurate prediction of the growth of the military.

pertinent.example: While the salaries of the players might draw attention in the media, such monetary figures are not pertinent to the question of who plays the best on the field.

perturb.example: Now that Henry is recovering from a major illnesses, he no longer lets the little trivialities, such as late mail, perturb him.

peruse.example: Instead of perusing important documents, people all too often rush to the bottom of the page and plaster their signatures at the bottom.

petulant.example: When Ed first met Ruth, he didn't realize she was so petulant, but now that they are three months into their relationship, Ed feels a day doesn't go by in which she isn't whining about some minor issue.

phantasmagorical.example: Those suffering from malaria fall into a feverish sleep, their world a whirligig of phantasmagoria; if they recover, they are unsure of what actually took place and what was simply a product of their febrile imaginations.

philistine.example: Jane considered Al completely philistine, because he talked almost exclusive about video games; she was entirely unaware of how well read he really was.
philistine.meaning: smug and ignorant towards artistic and cultural values
philistine.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

phlegmatic.example: Arnold is truly noble, remaining reserved until an issue of significance arises, but Walter is simply phlegmatic: he doesn't have the energy or inclination to care about anything.

picayune.example: English teachers are notorious for being picayune; however, the English language is so nuanced and sophisticated that often such teachers are not being contrary but are only adhering to the rules.

pillory.example: After the candidate confessed, the press of the opposing party took the opportunity to pillory him, printing editorials with the most blatantly exaggerated accusations.
pillory.meaning: ridicule or expose to public scorn
pillory.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pine.example: Standing forlornly by the window, she pined for her lost love.
pine.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pinnacle.example: At its pinnacle, the Roman Empire extended across most of the landmass of Eurasia, a feat not paralleled to the rise of the British Empire in the 18th and 19th century.

piquant.example: The chef, with a mere flick of the salt shaker, turned the bland tomato soup into a piquant meal.
piquant.meaning: having a pleasantly sharp taste or appetizing flavor

pith.example: When Cynthia hears a speaker presenting a complex argument, she is always able to discard the irrelevant details and extract the pith of what the speaker is trying to convey.
pith.meaning: the most essential part of something
pith.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

pithy.example: I enjoy reading the Daodejing for its pithy and insightful prose; it always gives me something to think about.
pithy.meaning: concise and full of meaning, substantial

pittance.example: Vinny's uncle beamed smugly about how he'd offered his nephew fifty dollars for his Harvard tuition; even twice the amount would have been a mere pittance.
pittance.meaning: a small or inadequate amount of money
