placate.example: I was able to placate the angry mob of students by promising to bring cookies on Monday.

placid.example: Doug is normally placid, so we were all shocked to see him yelling at the television when the Mets lost the game.

platitude.example: The professor argued that many statements regarded as wise in previous times, such as the Golden Rule, are now regarded as mere platitudes.
platitude.meaning: a remark that has been used too often to be interesting or thoughtful; commonplace statement; obvious remark

plodding.example: Charlie may seem to run at a plodding pace, but he is an ultramarathoner, meaning he runs distances of up to 100 miles, and can run for ten hours at a stretch.

plodding.meaning: thorough and hard-working but lacking in imagination or intelligence

ploy.example: Dennis arranged an elaborate ploy, involving 14 different people lying for him in different situations, so that it could appear that he was meeting Mary completely by chance at the wedding reception.
ploy.meaning: a clever plan to turn a situation to one's advantage

plucky.example: Some scouts initially doubted Pedroia because of his short stature, but he is a plucky player, surprising everyone with his boundless energy and fierce determination.

poignant.example: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet, in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken familes agree to end their feud once and for all.
poignant.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

polemic.example: The professor launched into a polemic, claiming that Freudian theory was a pack of lies that absolutely destroyed European literary theory.
polemic.meaning: a strong verbal or written attack; engagement in controversial debate or dispute
polemic.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ponderous.example: Laden with 20 kilograms of college text books, the freshman moved ponderously across the campus.

pontificate.example: The vice-president would often pontificate about economic theory, as if no one else in the room were qualified to speak on the topic.
pontificate.meaning: talk in a dogmatic and pompous manner
pontificate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

portentous.example: When the captain and more than half the officers were sick on the very first night of the voyage, many of the passengers felt this was portentous, but the rest of the voyage continued without any problems.

posit.example: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder.

powwow.example: Before the team takes the field, the coach always calls for a powwow so that he can make sure all the players are mentally in the right place.

pragmatic.example: Rather than make a philosophical appeal to the Congressmen, the Speaker decided to take a far more pragmatic approach, making small side-deals that would add votes to his bill.
pragmatic.meaning: guided by practical experience and observation rather than theory

precarious.example: People smoke to relax and forget their cares, but ironically, in terms of health risks, smoking is far more precarious than either mountain-climbing or skydiving.

precedent.example: The principal explained that even though one student had done modelling work outside of school, the outfits that student wore in those photographs in no way established a precedent for what could be worn at school dances.
precedent.meaning: an example used to justify similar occurrences at a later time

precipitate.example: Instead of conducting a thorough investigation after the city hall break-in, the governor acted precipitately, accusing his staff of aiding and abetting the criminals.
The government's mishandling the hurricane's aftermath precipitated a widespread outbreak of looting and other criminal activity.

precipitous.meaning: done with great haste and without careful consideration

precipitous.example: He was expecting a precipitous rise in the value of a "hot" tech stock, so he was disappointed when it only inched up a dollar or two each day.

preclude.example: The manager specified that all other gates be locked, to preclude the possibility of persons without tickets entering the arena undetected.

precocious.example: (especially in mental aptitude) Though only seven years old, she was a precocious chess prodigy, able to beat players twice her age.
precocious.meaning: advanced in development; having early maturity (of a child, behavior, plant)

predilection.example: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollar bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

preempt.example: A governmental warning about an imminent terrorist attack would preempt ordinary network programming on television.
preempt.meaning: take the place of or have precedence over

preemptive.example: Just as Martha was about to take the only cookie left on the table, Noah preemptively swiped it.
preemptive.meaning: taking action in order to prevent something from happening

prescience.example: Baxter's warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined significantly.
prescience.meaning: the power to foresee the future

presentiment.example: On the night that Lincoln would be fatally shot, his wife had a presentiment about going to Ford's Theater, but Lincoln persuaded her that everything would be fine.
presentiment.meaning: a feeling of evil to come

presumption.example: When Mr. Baker found out the family car was gone, he acted under the presumption that his rebellious son had taken the car, calling his son's phone and yelling at him; only later did Mr. Baker realize that Mrs. Baker had simply gone out to get her nails d
presumption.meaning: an assumption that is taken for granted

presumption.example: The new neighbor quickly gained a reptuation for her presumption; she had invited herself to several of the neighbors homes, often stopping over at inopportune times and asking for a drink.

presumptuous.example: Many felt that Barney was presumptuous in moving into the large office before the management even made any official announcement of his promotion.

prevail.example: During the labor negotiations, an air of hostility prevailed in the office.
prevail.meaning: be widespread in a particular area

prevail.example: Before the cricket match, Australia was heavily favored, but India prevailed.

prevaricate.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".
prevaricate.meaning: to speak in an evasive way

primacy.example: The primacy of Apple Computers is not guaranteed, as seen in the recent lawsuits and weak growth.
primacy.meaning: the state of being first in importance

pristine.example: The glacial lake was pristine and we filled our canteens to drink deeply.
pristine.meaning: in its original condition, unspoilt, untouched

pristine.example: Drill sergeants are known for demanding pristine cabinets, uniforms, and beds, and often make new recruits clean and clean and clean until they meet the expected high standards.
pristine.meaning: clean and fresh as if new, spotless

probity.example: The ideal politician would have the probity to lead, but reality gravely falls short of the ideal of morally upright leaders.

prodigal.example: Successful professional athletes who do not fall prey to prodigality seem to be the exception - most live decadent lives.

prodigious.example: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.
prodigious.meaning: impressively great in extent, size, or degree

profligate.example: The wife's profligate spending depleted all the savings of the husband. | Most lottery winners go from being conservative, frugal types to outright profligates who blow millions on fast cars, lavish homes, and giant yachts.
profligate.meaning: spending money recklessly or wastefully (also noun)

profligate.example: He succumbed to drink and a profligate lifestyle.

profuse.example: During mile 20 of the Hawaii Marathon, Dwayne was sweating so profusely that he stopped to take off his shirt, and ran the remaining six miles wearing nothing more than skimpy shorts.

profusion.example: When Maria reported that she had been visited by Jesus Christ and had proof, a profusion of reporters and journalists descended on the town.

prognostication.example: When the Senator was asked about where the negotiations would lead, he said that any guess he could make would be an unreliable prognostication.
prognostication.meaning: a statement made about the future

prolific.example: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

prolixity.example: I loved my grandfather dearly, but his prolixity would put me to sleep, regardless of the topic.

promulgate.example: The President wanted to promulgate the success of the treaty negotiations, but he had to wait until Congress formally approved the agreement.

propitiate.example: The two sons, plying their angry father with cheesy neckties for Christmas, were hardly able to propitiate him  -  the father already had a drawer full of ones he had never worn before or ever planned to.

propitious.example: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.
propitious.meaning: favorable; giving or indicating a good chance of success

proponent.example: Ironically, the leading proponent of Flat-Earth Theory flies all over the world in an effort to win more adherents.
proponent.meaning: a person who pleads for a cause or advocates an idea

prosaic.example: Unlike the talented artists in his workshop, Paul had no such bent for the visual medium, so when it was time for him to make a stained glass painting, he ended up with a prosaic mosaic.

proscribe.example: My doctor proscribes that I not eat donuts with chocolate sauce and hamburger patties for breakfast.

proselytize.example: Lisa loves her Mac but says little about it; by contrast, Jake will proselytize, interrogating anyone with an Android about why she didn't purchase an iPhone.
proselytize.meaning: convert to another religion, philosophy, or perspective

protean.example: Peter Sellers was truly a protean actor - in Doctor Strangelove he played three very different roles: a jingoist general, a sedate President and a deranged scientist.
protean.meaning: readily taking on different roles; versatile

provident.example: In a move that hardly could be described as provident, Bert spend his entire savings on a luxurious cruise, knowing that other bills would come due a couple months later.
provident.meaning: careful in regard to your own interests; providing carefully for the future

provincial.example: Maggie's enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.

provisional.example: Until the corporate office hands down a definitive decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.
provisional.meaning: arranged for the present and not fully agreed on

puerile.example: Helen enjoyed blowing soap bubbles, but Jim regarded this as puerile, totally unworthy of a woman with a Ph.D.
puerile.meaning: of or characteristic of a child; displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity

pugnacious.example: The comedian told one flat joke after another, and when the audience started booing, he pugnaciously back at them, "Hey, you think this is easy  -  why don"t you buffoons give it a shot?"
pugnacious.meaning: eager to fight or argue; verbally combative

puissant.example: Over the years of service, and quite to his surprise, he became a puissant advisor to the community.

punctilious.example: The colonel was so punctilious about enforcing regulations that men fell compelled to polish even the soles of their shoes.
punctilious.meaning: marked by precise accordance with details

pundit.example: Steven Pinker's credentials are unquestioned as a pundit; he has taught at MIT and Stanford, teaches at Harvard, and has published a number of influential books on cognition, language, and psychology.
pundit.meaning: someone who has been admitted to be an expert in particular field

pyrrhic.example: George W. Bush's win in the 2000 election was in many ways a pyrrhic victory: the circumstances of his win alienated half of the U.S. population.
pyrrhic.meaning: describing a victory that comes at such a great cost that the victory is not worthwhile

quail.example: Craig always claimed to be a fearless outdoorsman, but when the thunderstorm engulfed the valley, he quailed at the thought of leaving the safety of his cabin.
quail.meaning: draw back, as with fear or pain
quail.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

qualify.example: Chris qualified his love for San Francisco, adding that he didn't like the weather as much as the weather in Los Angeles. || Unable to give the candidate full support, the mayor gave him only a qualified endorsement.
qualify.meaning: to limit, restrict (a statement); to make less severe
qualify.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

qualm.example: While he could articulate no clear reason why Harkner's plan would fail, he neverless felt qualms about committing any resources to it.
qualm.meaning: uneasy feeling of doubt or fear, a misgiving

quandary.example: Steve certainly is in a quandary: if he doesn't call Elaine, she will blame him for everything, but if he does call her, the evidence of where he currently is could cost him his job.
quandary.meaning: dilemma, state of uncertainty or perplexity over what to do

querulous.example: The querulous old woman was begining to wear down even the happier members of the staff with her ceaseless complaining.
querulous.meaning_bg: който се оплаква и хленчи, недоволен

quip.example: In one of the most famous quips about classical music, Mark Twain said: "Wagner's music is better than it sounds."

quisling.example: History looks unfavorably upon quislings; indeed they are accorded about the same fondness as Nero - he who watched his city burn down while playing the violin.

quixotic.example: For every thousand startups with quixotic plans to be the next big name in e-commerce, only a handful ever become profitable.

quotidian.example: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle's arguments that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising and eating regularly.

raconteur.example: Jude is entertaining, but he is no raconteur: beyond the handful of amusing stories he has memorized, he has absolutely no spontaneous story-telling ability.
raconteur.meaning: a person skilled in telling anecdotes

raffish.example: The men found him raffish, but the women adored his smart clothes and casual attitude.
raffish.meaning: unconventional and slightly disreputable, especially in an attractive way

raft.example: Despite a raft of city ordinances passed by an overzealous council, noise pollution continued unabated in the megalopolis.
raft.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

raillery.example: The new recruit was not bothered by the raillery, finding most of it light-hearted and good-natured.

rakish.example: As soon as he arrived in the city, the rakish young man bought some drugs and headed straight for the seedy parts of town.
rakish.meaning: having carefree, dashing and disreputable appearance

rankle.example: His constant whistling would rankle her, sometimes causing her to leave in a huff.

rapprochement.example: Although Ann hoped that her mother and her aunt would have a rapprochement, each one's bitter accusations against the other made any reconciliation unlikely.

rarefied.example: Jack's vulgar jokes were not so successful in the rarefied enviroment of college professors.
rarefied.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

rash.example: Although Bruce was able to make the delivery in time with a nightime motorcycle ride in the rain, Susan criticized his actions as rash.
rash.meaning: done without careful consideration of the possible consequences; impetuous
rash.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

ravenous.example: John didn't each much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surpring that he has a ravenous appetite.
ravenous.meaning: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities

rebuke.example: The police chief rebuked the two officers whose irresponsible decisions almost led to the deaths of seven innocent by-standers.

recapitulation.example: Every point of the professors lesson was so clear that the students felt his concluding recapitulation was not necessary.

reconcile.example: Peggy was unable to reconcile her kind friend Jane with the cruel and merciless character Jane played on television.

recondite.example: I found Ulysses recondite and never finished the book, waiting instead to read it with someone else so we could penetrate its meaning together.

recrimination.example: The two brothers sat and cried, pointing fingers and making elaborate recriminations of the other's guilt

recrudesce.example: After years of gamblers anonymous, Tony thought he'd broken his compulsive slot machine playing, but it took only one trip to the Atlantic City for a full recrudescence - he lost $5k on the one armed bandit.
recrudesce.meaning: to break out or happen again

redoubtable.example: On television basketball players don't look that tall, but when you stand in front of a seven-foot tall NBA player, he is truly redoubtable.

redress.example: Barry forgot his wife's birthday two years in a row, and was only able to redress his oversight by surprising his wife with a trip to Tahiti.
redress.meaning: an act of making something right, remedy, compensation
redress.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

refractory.example: Used to studious high school students, Martha was unprepared for the refractory Kindgergarteners who neither sat still nor listened to a single word she said.
refractory.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

refute.example: No one could refute his theories or propositions, and that is why he was esteemed by all his colleagues in the philosophy department.
refute.meaning: prove to be false or incorrect

relegate.example: When Dexter was unable to fulfill his basic duties, instead of firing him, the boss relegated him to kitchen cleanup.

remiss.example: Remiss in his duty to keep the school functioning efficiently, the principle was relieved of his position after only three months.
remiss.meaning: negligent; lacking care or attention to duty

remonstrate.example: The mothers of the kidnapped victims remonstrated to the rogue government to release their children, claiming that the detention violated human rights.

renege.example: We will no longer work with that vendor since it has reneged on nearly every agreement.
renege.meaning: fail to fulfill a promise or obligation

replete.example: Only weeks after the hurricane made landfall, the local supermarket shelves were replete with goods, so quick was the disaster relief response.
replete.meaning: filled to the point of being stuffed, abundantly supplied

reprisal.example: The Old Testament doctrine of an eye for an eye is not the kind of retaliation practiced in war; rather, an arm, a leg, and both ears are the reprisal for the smallest scratch.
reprisal.meaning: a retaliatory action against an enemy in wartime

reproach.example: At first, Sarah was going to yell at the boy, but she didn't want to reproach him for telling the truth about the situation.

reprobate.example: Those old reprobates drinking all day down by the river - they are not going to amount to much.
reprobate.meaning: a person who is disapproved of

repudiate.example: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.
repudiate.meaning: reject as untrue or unfounded; refuse to accept

rescind.example: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

reservation.example: I was initially excited by the idea of a trip to Washington, D.C. but now that I have read about the high crime statistics there, I have some reservations.
reservation.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resignation.example: Since Jack could not think of a convincing reason why he had to miss the seminar, he attended it with a sense of resignation.
resignation.meaning: the acceptance of something undesirable but inevitable
resignation.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

resolve.example: After much thought, Ted resolved not to travel abroad this summer because he didn't have much money in his bank account.
resolve.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

respite.example: Every afternoon, the small company has a respite in which workers play foosball or board games.
respite.meaning: short rest or relief from work or something difficult or unpleasant

restive.example: The crowd grew restive as the comedian's opening jokes fell flat.

resurgent.example: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.
resurgent.meaning: rising again or reviving after a period of little activity or popularity

reticent.example: When asked about her father, Helen lost her outward enthusiasm and became rather reticent.
reticent.meaning: reluctant to draw attention to himself; disinclined to talk

retiring.example: Nelson was always the first to leave soirees - rather than mill about with "fashionable" folk, he was retiring, and preferred the solitude of his garret.
retiring.meaning: shy and fond of being on one's own

retract.example: Email is wonderfully efficient, but once something awkward or damaging has been sent, there is no way to retract it.

reverent.example: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

ribald.example: The speaker was famous for his ribald humor, but the high school principal asked him to keep the talk Grated when he spoke to the student body.

rile.example: Dan is usually calm and balanced, but it takes only one intense glare from Sabrina to rile him.

robust.example: Chris preferred bland and mild beers, but Bhavin preferred a beer with more robust flavor.
robust.meaning: sturdy and strong in form or construction

row.example: The Prime Minister looked very foolish after his row with the foreign dignitary was caught on video and posted on youtube.
row.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

rudimentary.example: I would love to be able to present a fully polished proposal to the board, but right now, our plans for the product are still in the most rudimentary stages.
rudimentary.meaning: in the earliest stages of development; involving or limited to basic principles

rustic.example: The vacation cabin had no electricity and no indoor plumbing, but despite these inconveniences, Nigel adored its rustic charm.

sagacious.example: Steve Jobs is surely one of the most sagacious CEOs, making Apple the most recognizable and valuable companies in the world.
sagacious.meaning: having good judgement and acute insight

sanctimonious.example: Even during the quiet sanctity of evening prayer, she held her chin high, a sanctimonious sneer forming on her face as she eyed those who were attending church for the first time.

sanction.example: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers an campers enjoying the park in the coming months.
International sanctions have been placed on certain shipping lanes that were thought to be involved in human trafficking.
sanction.meaning: a legal penalty for a forbidden action

sangfroid.example: The hostage negotiator exhibited a sangfroid that oftentimes was more menacing than the sword at his throat, or the gun at his head.
sangfroid.meaning: calmness or poise in difficult situations

sanguine.example: With the prospect of having to learn 3,000 words during the course of the summer, Paul was anything but sanguine.
sanguine.meaning: positive, optimistic, especially in apparently bad situation

sardonic.example: A stand-up comedian walks a fine line when making jokes about members of the audience; such fun and joking can quickly become sardonic and cutting.
sardonic.meaning: disdainfully or ironically humorous; scornful and mocking

sartorial.example: Monte was astute at navigating the world of finance; sartorially, however, he was found wanting - he typically would attempt to complement his beige tie with a gray suit and white pants.

saturnine.example: Deprived of sunlight, humans become saturnine; that's why in very northerly territories people are encouraged to sit under an extremely powerful lamp, lest they become morose.

savvy.example: Although a great CEO, he did not have the political savvy to win the election.
The student savvies the meaning of astrophysics with little effort.
With his savvy business partner, the company was able to turn a profit within a year.

schadenfreude.example: From his warm apartment window, Stanley reveled in schadenfreude as he laughed at the figures below, huddled together in the arctic chill.
schadenfreude.meaning: joy from watching the suffering of others

scintillating.example: Richard Feynman was renowned for his scintillating lectures - the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.
scintillating.meaning: shining brightly, sparkling; brilliant (for a person)

screed.example: Joey had difficulty hanging out with his former best friend Perry, who, during his entire cup of coffee, enumerated all of the government's deficiencies - only to break ranks and launch into some screed against big business.

scrupulous.example: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.
scrupulous.meaning: careful, thorough, and extremely attentive to details

scrupulous.example: Everyone trusted what he said and followed his example because he was scrupulous and honest.
scrupulous.meaning: very concerned to avoid doing wrong; principled

sedulous.example: An avid numismatist, Harold sedulously amassed a collection of coins from over 100 countries - an endeavor that took over fifteen years, and to five continents.

self-effacing.example: The most admirable teachers and respected leaders are those who are self-effacing, directing attention and praise to their students and workers.

semblance.example: While the banker maintained a semblance of respectability in public, those who knew him well were familiar with his many crimes.
semblance.meaning: an outward or token appearance or form that is deliberately misleading

sententious.example: The old man, casting his nose up in the air at the group of adolescents, intoned sententiously, "Youth is wasted on the young."
sententious.meaning: to be moralizing, usually in a pompous sense

sentimental.example: I don't like romanticism for the same reason I don't like melodramatic acting and soap operas - overly sentimental.

serendipity.example: By pure serendipity, Sarah discovered, at a flea market in Peoria, a matching earring to replace the one that fell down the storm drain back home.
serendipity.meaning: accidental good fortune, luck or fortunate discovery

serene.example: I'd never seen him so serene; usually, he was a knot of stress and anxiety from hours of trading on the stock exchange.

simulacrum.example: The Shanghai Urban Planning Exhibition Center showcases a simulacrum of all the present and approved buildings in the city of Shanghai.
simulacrum.meaning: a representation of a person (especially in the form of sculpture)

simulacrum.example: The early days of computer graphics made real people into a simalacrum that now seems comical.

sinecure.example: The position of Research Director is a sinecure: the job entails almost no responsibilities, nor does the person in that position have to answer to anyone.
sinecure.meaning: an office that involves minimal duties

slapdash.example: The office building had been constructed in a slapdash manner, so it did not surprise officials when, during a small earthquake, a large crack emerged on the facade of the building.

smattering.example: I know only a smattering of German, but Helen is able to read German newspapers and converse with natives.
smattering.meaning: a slight superficial knowledge of a subject, a small amount of

smug.example: When Phil was dating the model, he had a smug attitude that annoyed his buddies.

snide.example: The chairman interpreted Taylor's question about promotions as a snide remark, but in all innocence Taylor was trying to figure out the company's process.
snide.meaning: expressive of contempt; derogatory or mocking in an indirect way

snub.example: Wheeler was completely qualified for the committee, but the board snubbed him, choosing an obviously lesser qualified candidate instead.

solecism.example: Mother Anna was always on guard against any solecism from her children and scolded them immediately if any of them talked out of place in public.
solecism.meaning: a socially awkward or tactless act
solecism.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

solicitous.example: Our neighbors are constantly knocking on our door to make sure we are ok, and I don't know how to ask them to stop being so solicitous about our health.
solicitous.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

solicitude.example: I walked to his house in the rain to make sure he had enough to eat while he was sick, but he seemed not to appreciate my solicitude.

soporific.example: Although the professor is brilliant, his bland monotone gives his lectures a soporific effect.

sordid.example: and run-down and repulsive The nightly news simply announced that the senator had had an affair, but the tabloid published all the sordid details of the interaction.
sordid.meaning: involving ignoble actions, arousing moral contempt, foul
sordid.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

spartan.example: After losing everything in a fire, Tim decided to live in spartan conditions, sleeping on the floor and owning as little furniture as a possible.
spartan.meaning: unsparing and uncompromising in discipline or judgment; practicing great selfdenial

specious.example: Almost every image on TV is specious and not to be trusted.
He made a career out of specious arguments and fictional lab results, but lost his job and reputation when his lies were exposed by an article in The New York Times.

spendthrift.example: Taking weekly trips to Vegas, Megan was a spendthrift whose excesses eventually caught up to her.

splenetic.example: Ever since the car accident, Frank has been unable to walk without a cane, and so he has become splenetic and unpleasant to be around.

sporadic.example: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation eminating from deep space.

spurious.example: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

spurn.example: She spurned all his flattery and proposals, and so he walked off embarrassed and sad.

squander.example: Fearing his money would be squandered by his family, he gave all of it to charity when he died.

squelch.example: After the dictator consolidated his power, he took steps to squelch all criticism, often arresting any journalist who said anything that could be interpreted as negative about his regime.

staid.example: Frank came from a staid enviroment, so he was shocked that his college rooommate sold narcotics.

stalwart.example: Despite all the criticism directed at the President during this scandal, Lisa has remained his stalwart supporter.
stalwart.meaning: dependable; inured to fatigue or hardships

start.example: All alone in the mansion, Henrietta started when she heard a sound.
start.meaning: jerk or suddenly jump from surprise or alarm
start.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

staunch.example: No longer a staunch supporter of the movement, Todd now will openly question whether its goals are worthwhile.
staunch.meaning: very loyal and committed in attitude

steadfast.example: A good captain needs to be steadfast, continuing to hold the wheel and stay the course even during the most violent storm.

stem.example: To stem the tide of applications, the prestigious Ivy requires that each applicant score at least 330 on the Revised GRE.
stem.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

stingy.example: Scrooge was an ungenerous old skinflint until he reformed his ways and became a notable philanthropist.

stipend.example: He was hoping for a monthly allowance loan from the government, but after no such stipend was forthcoming he realized he would have to seek other means of paying for his college tuition.

stolid.example: Elephants may appear stolid to casual observers, but they actually have passionate emotional lives.
stolid.meaning: showing little emotion or animation, unruffled

stringent.example: Most of the students disliked the teacher because of his stringent homework policy, but many students would later thank him for demanding so much from them.

stultify.example: As an undergraduate Mark felt stultified by classes outside his area of study; only in grad school, in which he could focus solely on literary analysis, did he regain his scholarly edge.
stultify.meaning: cause one, through routine, to lose energy and enthusiasm

stymie.example: The engineers found their plans stymied at every turn and were ultimately able to make amlost no progress on the project.
stymie.meaning: hinder or prevent the progress of

subsume.example: The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier and boardwalk, destroying everything in its path. | Don Quixote of La Mancha subsumes all other modern novels, demonstrating modern literary devices and predating even the idea of a postmodern, metanarrative.
subsume.meaning: include or absorb (something in something else)

subterfuge.example: Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.
subterfuge.meaning: something intended to misrepresent the true nature of an activity

subversive.example: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to "national safety."
subversive.meaning: seeking to undermine the power of an established system or institution

sullen.example: Herbert took board games too seriously, often appearing sullen after losing.

summit.example: After hiking for two days, the climbers finally reached the summit of Mount Kilimanjaro.
Since climate change policy has been mired in congressional fighting, this summit should help set the goals for president's next term.

supercilious.example: Nelly felt the Quiz Bowl director acted superciliously towards the underclassmen; really, she fumed, must he act so preternaturally omniscient each time he intones some obscure fact - as though everybody knows that Mt. Aconcagua is the highest peak in Sout
supercilious.meaning: haughty and disdainful; looking down on others

superfluous.example: How can we hope to stay open if we don't eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupucture Tuesday?
Everything in this closet is superfluous and can be given to charity.
superfluous.meaning: redundant, unnecessary, more than is needed

supplant.example: For many, a cell phone has supplanted a traditional phone; in fact, most 20-somethings don't even have a traditional phone anymore.

surfeit.example: There was no such thing as a surfeit of shopping for Nancy - she could stay at the outlet stores from opening to closing time.

surly.example: Every morning, Bhavin was a surly unhappy person, but once he ate breakfast, he became loving, laughing, and a joy to be around.

surreptitious.example: Since his mom was a light sleeper, Timmy had to tiptoe surreptitiously through the entire house, careful to not make the floors creak, until he at last was able to enjoy his plunder: a box of chocolate chip cookies.
surreptitious.meaning: stealty, taking pains not to be caught or detected

sybarite.example: Despite the fact that he'd maxed out fifteen credit cards, Max was still a sybarite at heart: when the police found him, he was at a $1,000 an hour spa in Manhattan, getting a facial treatment.
sybarite.meaning: a person who indulges in luxury

sycophant.example: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.
sycophant.meaning: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage

taciturn.example: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

tact.example: In a tremendous display of tact, Shelly was able to maintain a strong friendship with Marcia, even though Marcia's husband, Frank, confessed to finding Shelley more attractive than Marcia.
tact.meaning: skill and sensitivity in dealing with others

tantamount.example: In many situations, remaining silent is tantamount to admitting guilt, so speak to prove your innocence.
tantamount.meaning: equivalent in seriousness; virtually the same as

tarnish.example: Pete Rose was one of the best baseball players of his generation, but his involvement with gambling on baseball games has tarnished his image in the eyes of many.
tarnish.meaning: make or become less valuable or respected

tawdry.example: Carol expected to find New York City magical, the way so many movies had portrayed it, but she was surprised how often tawdry displays took the place of genuine elegance.
tawdry.meaning: showy but cheap and of poor quality

taxing.example: The hike to the summit of Mt. Whitney was so taxing that I could barely speak or stand up.
taxing.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

telling.example: Her unbecoming dress was very telling when it came to her sense of fashion.

telltale.example: The many telltale signs of chronic smoking include yellow teeth, and a persistent, hacking cough.

temerity.example: No child has the temerity to go in the rundown house at the end of the street and see if it is haunted.

temperance.example: Welles wasn't known for his temperance - he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.
temperance.meaning: moderation in action; the trait of avoiding excesses (often used for eating or drinking)

tempered.example: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

tempestuous.example: changing or fluctuating Chuck and Kathy had always been stable and agreeable people on their own, but when they got involved, it was a tempestuous relationship.
tempestuous.meaning: as if driven by turbulent or conflicting emotions; highly energetic and wildly

tenacious.example: Even the most tenacious advocates for gun ownership must admit some of the dangers that firearms present.

tendentious.example: Because political mudslinging has become a staple of the 24-hour media cycle, most of us, despite protestations to the contrary, are tendentious on many of today's pressing issues.
tendentious.meaning: likely to lean towards a controversial view

tender.example: The government was loath to tender more money in the fear that it might set off inflation.
tender.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

tenuous.example: The allegiance of our allies is based on such tenuous ties that we have little hope they will remain loyal.

thoroughgoing.example: As a thoroughgoing bibliophile, one who had turned his house into a veritable library, he shocked his friends when he bought a Kindle.
thoroughgoing.meaning: exemplifying a specified characteristic fully; absolute

thrifty.example: He was economical, spending his money thriftily and on items considered essential.

thwart.example: I wanted to spend a week in New York this autumn, but the high costs of travel and lodging thwarted my plans.

timorous.example: Since this was her first time debating on stage and before an audience, Di's voice was timorous and quiet for the first 10 minutes.

tirade.example: In terms of political change, a tirade oftentimes does little more than make the person speaking red in the face.

torpor.example: After work, I was expecting my colleagues to be enthusiastic about the outing, but I found them in a state of complete torpor.
torpor.meaning: physical or mental inactivity due to lack of vigor

tortuous.example: Because the logic behind McMahon's side of the debate was so tortuous, his audience came out either completely confused or, worse, feeling they'd been tricked.
tortuous.meaning: full of twists and turns, not straightforward; excessively lengthy and complex

tout.example: At the conference, the CEO touted the extraordinary success of his company's Research & Development division.
tout.meaning_bg: натрапвам, хваля шумно, навирам в очите

tractable.example: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.
tractable.meaning: easy to control or influence; easily managed

transient.example: The unpredictable and transient nature of deja vu makes it a very difficult phenomenon to study properly.

transitory.example: If we lived forever and life was not transitory, do you think we would appreciate life less or more?

transmute.example: One of the goals of alchemy was to find the substance or process that would transmute lead into gold.
transmute.meaning: change or alter in form, appearance, or nature

travail.example: While they experienced nothing but travails in refinishing the kitchen, they completed the master bedroom in less than a weekend.

travesty.example: What I expected to be an intelligent, nuanced historical documentary turned out to be a poorly-produced travesty of the form.
travesty.meaning: a false, absurd or distorted presentation of something; a mockery

treacherous.example: Even though Jesse James was an outlaw, his killer, Robert Ford, is remembered more for his treacherous actions than for eliminating a criminal and murder.
The bridge built from twine and vine is treacherous to walk across, and so I think I will stay put right here.

trenchant.example: penetration in thought, expression, or intellect Jill presented a rather superficial treatment of sales in Asia, but her trenchant analysis of sales in Europe inspired a number of insights into how to proceed in that market.
trenchant.meaning: characterized by or full of force and vigor; having keenness and forcefulness and

tribulation.example: As of 2013, nearly 1.5 million Syrians have fled their country hoping to escape the tribulations of a civil war tearing their country to pieces.
tribulation.meaning: a cause of great difficulty or suffering

trite.example: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.
trite.meaning: repeated too often; dull on account of overuse

truculence.example: When the boss confronted Aaron about his earlier remarks, Aaron responded with utter truculence, simply throwing a glass of water in the boss' face and walking away.

truculent.example: Standing in line for six hours, she became progressively truculent, yelling at DMV employees and elbowing other people waiting in line.

truncate.example: The soccer game was truncated when the monsoon rain began to fall.

tumult.example: Riots broke out just in front of our apartment building, and the tumult continued late into the night.
tumult.meaning: a state of chaos, noise and confusion

turgid.example: The amount of GRE vocabulary he used increased with his years - by the time he was 60, his novels were so turgid that even his diehard fans refused to read them.

turpitude.example: During his reign, Caligula indulged in unspeakable sexual practices, so it not surprising that he will forever be remembered for his turpitude.

tyro.example: All great writers, athletes, and artists were tyros at one time - unknown, clumsy, and unskilled with much to learn.
tyro.meaning: someone new to a field or activity

umbrage.example: Since he was so in love with her, he took umbrage at her comments, even though she had only meant to gently tease him.
umbrage.meaning: a feeling of anger caused by being offended

unassailable.example: Professor Williams is so self-assured as to seem arrogant, presenting each and every opinion as an unassailable fact.

uncanny.example: normal Reggie has an uncanny ability to connect with animals: feral cats will readily approach him, and sometimes even wild birds will land on his finger.

uncompromising.example: The relationship between Bart and Hilda ultimately failed because they were both so uncompromising, never wanting to change their opinions.

unconscionable.example: The lawyer's demands were so unconscionable that rather than pay an exorbitant sum or submit himself to any other inconveniences, the defendant decided to find a new lawyer.

undermine.example: The student undermined the teacher's authority by questioning the teacher's judgment on numerous occasions.
undermine.meaning: to weaken (usually paired with an abstract term)

underscore.example: While the hiking instructor agreed that carrying a first aid kit could be a good idea under certain circumstances, he underscored the importance of carrying enough water.

underwrite.example: The latest symphony broadcast was made possible with underwriting from the Carnegie Endowment.

unequivocal.example: The President's first statement on the subject was vague and open to competing interpretations, so when he spoke to Congress about the same subject later, he was careful to make his position completely unequivocal.
unequivocal.meaning: leaving no doubt or misunderstanding; unambiguous

unflappable.example: composure The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.
unflappable.meaning: not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and

unforthcoming.example: The teacher demanded to know who broke the window while he was out of the room, but the students understandably were unforthcoming.
unforthcoming.meaning: uncooperative, not willing to give up information

unimpeachable.example: After his long and unimpeachable service to the company, Sharat felt that a gold watch was a slap in the face rather than an honor.
unimpeachable.meaning: free of guilt; not subject to blame; beyond doubt or reproach

unnerve.example: At one time unnerved by math problems, she began avidly "Magoosh-ing", and soon became adept at even combinations and permutations questions.
unnerve.meaning: upset; make someone lose courage or confidence

unprecedented.example: When America first created its national parks, the idea of setting aside the most beautiful land in a country was unprecedented in the history of mankind.
unprecedented.meaning: never done or known before, novel

unprepossessing.example: World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.
unprepossessing.meaning: creating an unfavorable or neutral first impression

unpropitious.example: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.
unpropitious.meaning: (of a circumstance) with little chance of success

unruly.example: Walk in to any preschool and I am sure that you will find an unruly and chaotic scene - unless it's nap time.
unruly.meaning: disorderly, disruptive and not amenable to discipline or control, disobedient

unscrupulous.example: In the courtroom, the lawyer was unscrupulous, using every manner of deceit and manipulation to secure a victory for himself.

unseemly.example: He acted in an unseemly manner, insulting the hostess and then speaking ill of her deceased husband.

unstinting.example: Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.

untenable.example: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.
untenable.meaning: (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified

untoward.example: Some professors find teaching untoward as having to prepare for lectures and conduct office hours prevents them from focusing on their research.

untrammeled.example: The whole notion of living untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

unviable.example: The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.
unviable.meaning: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).

upbraid.example: Bob took a risk walking into the "Students Barbershop" - in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

urbane.example: Because of his service as an intelligence officer and his refined tastes, W. Somerset Maugham became the inspiration for the urbane and sophistcated spy James Bond.

vacillate.example: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.
vacillate.meaning: be indecisive; waver between different opinions or actions
vacillate.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

vacuous.example: To the journalist's pointed question, the senator gave a vacuous response, mixing a few of his overall campaign slogans with platitudes and completely avoiding the controversial subject of the question.
vacuous.meaning: devoid of intelligence, matter, or significance

vanquish.example: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.

variance.example: The cynic quipped, "There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate".
variance.meaning: the quality of being different and varying

vaunted.example: For years, they had heard of New York City's vaunted skyline, and when they finally saw it, the spectacular cityscape did not disappoint them in the least.
vaunted.meaning: highly or widely praised or boasted about

vehement.example: While the other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

venality.example: Even some of the most sacrosanct sporting events are not immune to venality, as many of the officials have received substantial bribes to make biased calls.
venality.meaning: the condition of being susceptible to bribes or corruption

veneer.example: Mark Twain referred to the Victorian Period in America as the "Gilded Age", implying the ample moral corruption that lay beneath a mere veneer of respectability.
veneer.meaning: thin superficial covering that hides the underlying substance

venerate.example: The professor, despite his soporific lectures, was venerated amongst his colleagues, publishing more papers yearly than all of his peers combined.

venial.example: His traffic violations ran the gamut from the venial to the egregious - on one occasion he simply did not come to a complete stop; another time he tried to escape across state lines at speeds in excess of 140 mph.

veracious.example: While we elect our leaders in the hope that every word they speak will be veracious, history has shown that such a hope is naive.

verisimilitude.example: All bad novels are bad for numerous reasons; all good novels are good for their verisimilitude of reality, placing the readers in a world that resembles the one they know.

veritable.example: Frank is a veritable life-saver  -  last year, on two different occasions, he revived people using CPR.

vicarious.example: The advent of twitter is a celebrity stalker's dream, as he or she can - through hundreds of intimate "tweets" - vicariously live the life of a famous person.
vicarious.meaning: felt or undergone as if one were taking part in the experience or feelings of another

vicissitude.example: Even great rulers have their vicissitudes - massive kingdoms have diminished overnight, and once beloved kings have faced the scorn of angry masses.
vicissitude.meaning: change in one"s circumstances, usually for the worse

vie.example: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.

vilify.example: Todd was noble after the divorce, choosing to say only complimentary things about Barbara, but Barbara did not hesitate to vilify Todd.

vindicate.example: Even seven Tour de France wins cannot vindicate Lance Armstrong in the eyes of the public - that the athlete used performance enhancing drugs invalidates all those wins.
vindicate.meaning: to clear of accusation or blame with supporting arguments or proof

vindictive.example: Though the other girl had only lightly poked fun of Vanessa's choice in attire, Vanessa was so vindictive that she waited for an entire semester to get the perfect revenge.
vindictive.meaning: having a strong desire for revenge

virago.example: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago's invective - she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in public.

vitriol.example: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racisim that consumed his whole life.
vitriol.meaning: abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will

vitriolic.example: While the teacher was more moderate in her criticism of the other student's papers, she was vitriolic toward Peter's paper, casting every flaw in the harshest light.

vituperate.example: Jason had dealt with disciplinarians before, but nothing prepared him for the first week of boot camp, as drill sergeants vituperated him for petty oversights such as forgetting to double knot the laces on his boots.

vociferous.example: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around an look at them angrily.
vociferous.meaning: conspicuously and offensively loud; characterized by vehement opinions

volubility.example: The professor's volubility knows no bounds; he could talk through a hurricane and elaborate a point from one St. Patrick's Day to the next.
volubility.meaning: the quality of talking  fluently, easily, or incessantly

voracious.example: Steven was a voracious reader, sometimes finishing two novels in the same day.
voracious.meaning: very hungry; having a very eager approach to an activity
voracious.meaning_bg: лаком, ненаситен (и в преносен позитивен смисъл)

wanting.example: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitably she found a few she didn't know.

wanton.example: Due to wanton behavior and crude language, the drunk man was thrown out of the bar and asked to never return.
wanton.meaning: unrestrained, promiscuous, showing no moral restraints

wax.example: Her enthusiasm for the diva's new album only waxed with each song; by the end of the album, it was her favorite CD yet.
wax.note: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one for the GRE

whimsical.example: Adults look to kids and envy their whimsical nature at times, wishing that they could act without reason and play without limitation.
whimsical.meaning: determined by impulse or whim rather than by reason
